It has been over a year since Congress first asked for this investigation, and now the public needs to know the status and findings. Every day that the FCC delays reporting their findings puts consumers’ personal security at greater risk.

That means that for just a few dollars, stalkers and predatory abusers can buy geolocation information that has made its way to the black market to prey on unsuspecting victims -- a reality that should set off alarm bells nationwide.
Location data is sold through a supply chain with little oversight, which can often lead to this information ending up in the hands of bad actors.

THREAD: #ICYMI: This week I successfully amended the FY20 FSGG appropriations bill to compel the @FCC to share the findings of their investigation into the sale of geolocation data by wireless carriers to third parties.

We have an obligation to safeguard those who answer the call to service by confronting the root causes of sexual assault in the military.

The body would advise the secretary on ways to implement new or improve existing programs dedicated to preventing sexual assault & would be comprised of members with expertise in campus sexual assault, suicide prevention, public health, and culture change of large organizations.

My second amendment incorporated legislation that I introduced earlier this week — the bipartisan & bicameral “Prevention of Sexual Assault in the Armed Forces Act.” This bill directs the Secretary of Defense to create a civilian advisory committee on sexual assault prevention.

This means that teachers and counselors can better identify students who may need additional support, and provide invaluable data for educators, parents, and policymakers to better understand academic outcomes of military connected students.

THREAD: As I work my way through #FY20NDAA (my first!), I’m pleased that 2 of my amendments have been included in the overall bill so far. The first includes children w/ parents in the National Guard or Reserve Component in the military student identifier definition of the ESSA. pic.twitter.com/ra0Eb5DHfV

Patricia, like thousands of others caught up in this discriminatory policy, does not deserve this treatment. We know from testimony of top military officials this ban is not rooted in any legitimate need, only an underlying bigotry against servicemembers who deserve respect. 3/4

This provision is particularly important given the Administration’s previous attempt to block the @USEEOC from collecting this data. Thankfully, earlier this month the @nwlc won their legal challenge, reinstating the EEOC’s ability to collect this wage data. Let’s make it law. https://twitter.com/RepLoriTrahan/status/1111000651805409281 …
Simply put, we cannot end unfair pay discrimination if we don’t have the data. #ForThePeople #EqualPayForEqualWork 3/3

There's no question that gender pay discrimination persists, often in subtle ways that can't be easily detected. It is important for the @USEEOC to collect this data to reveal trends in hiring, compensation, and advancement to expose unequal salaries, benefits, or bonuses. 2/3

A key component of the #PaycheckFairnessAct requires that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission collect wage data – broken down by sex, race, and national origin. Today I spoke out against an amendment that would have gutting that provision. 1/3 pic.twitter.com/FW3TPL4VnS

Businesses and employees benefit from an increase in the federal minimum wage. The #RaiseTheWageAct will reduce absenteeism, increase employee morale, and put more money in the pockets of American families.

The #RaisetheWage Act will gradually increase the federal minimum wage from its current $7.25 per hour to $15 per hour. That’s good for workers, businesses, and our economy. It’s time to #RaisetheWage.

Not only do women make up 2/3 of minimum wage workers, they also face a wage gap, both of which hold them back from reaching their full economic potential. I'm proud to support the #RaiseTheWageAct, giving 20+ million women a well-deserved raise!

Historians look back at this event and agree: it not only represented a tipping point for mill workers in Lawrence and New England, but for the labor movement across the entire US.
In #Lawrence, it was women who helped lead the 1912 “Bread and Roses” Strike to fight for a fair wage, safer working conditions, and a brighter future for their families.

In #Lowell, a half-century before better-known movements for workers' rights in the US, it was women working in Lowell mills that organized, mobilized, & went on strike for better wages & working conditions. Their efforts created the first union of working women in US history.
This #LaborDay I am I am thinking of our own history right here in Lowell and Lawrence. In the early 1900’s cities like Lawrence and Lowell helped forge the modern labor movement. #MA3

GONE: Support for rural hospitals. As Americans lose coverage, already struggling hospitals will be hit even harder.

GONE: Ban on insurance companies having lifetime caps on coverage.

GONE: Requirements that insurance companies cover prescription drugs and maternity care.

GONE: 2.3 million individuals will no longer be able to stay on their parents’ insurance.

GONE: Insurance companies will be able to charge women 50 percent more than men.

GONE: Financial assistance that helps 9 million people purchase health care in the marketplace.

GONE: Protections for 130 million Americans with pre-existing conditions. 

GONE: Medicaid expansion, which covers 17 million people.

GONE: Nearly 12 million seniors will have to pay more for prescription drugs

The Administration is trying to tear apart the United States health care system by going to court to eliminate the Affordable Care Act in its entirety. We can't let that happen. This is some of what will be lost if the #ACA is struck down: [THREAD]

BREAKING: The House just voted to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act (#VAWA), H.R. 1585. 

My full statement here: https://trahan.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=98 …

The reauthorization makes critical new investments in abuse prevention, enhances vital law enforcement tools, bolsters support resources for survivors, and much more. Every American -- every woman -- has the right to live free from abuse.

Each time Congress has reauthorized VAWA, they have strengthened it to improve protections and access to safety and justice for survivors.

I was proud to continue in that tradition today by voting in favor of this VAWA reauthorization.

Domestic violence remains far too common with as many as one in three women in the United States still experiencing abuse. The landmark Violence Against Women Act of 1994 ushered in transformative progress by calling for the protection of all Americans from violence and abuse. https://twitter.com/NPR/status/1113844078817501185 …

No person should have to decide between putting food on the table or being able to care for a sick loved one.

One of the main reasons I ran for office was to make life better for women and hardworking families just like the one I grew up in. Ushering in a new, national paid family leave policy for the United States is one of the most significant steps Congress can take to do just that.

Family #PaidLeave legislation would empower women, strengthen families, support businesses, and grow the U.S. economy. I am proud to be a cosponsor, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to get this bill signed into law. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/paid-family-leave-democrats_us_5c61bbfce4b0eec79b26b140 …

Can you imagine being forced to choose between putting food on the table or taking care of a sick loved one? No one should have to think about it, let alone experience it. That is why I am a cosponsor of the #FAMILYAct. It is time for a national #PaidLeave policy that works.

LGBTQ+ people often have to face down additional hurdles to access paid family leave. Passing the #FAMILYAct would ensure they don't risk their economic livelihood to care for a loved one. 

Thank you, @HRC, for being an ally in the fight for #PaidLeave!

The #FAMILYAct would guarantee #PaidLeave for moms and dads (and many others!). A national paid leave policy is urgently needed to shift care-giving norms and to make workplaces more equitable and family friendly. I am proud to cosponsor this legislation. pic.twitter.com/zSowVxz403
